title: How to Qualify a General Contractor for Fix-and-Flip Projects
excerpt: Choosing the right general contractor (GC) is critical for a profitable fix-and-flip. A qualified GC keeps your project on schedule, on budget, and compliant with all regulations. Use this checklist to confidently vet GCs and avoid costly mistakes.

content.text: Why GC Qualification Matters for Fix-and-Flips

In the fast-paced world of fix-and-flip investing, hiring the wrong GC can mean blown budgets, missed deadlines, and legal headaches. A proven, reliable GC will help you avoid delays, minimize risk, and maximize your return on investment.

items: Licensing: Verify the GC holds a valid state contractor’s license with no violations. Use your state’s licensing board to confirm.
Insurance: Require proof of liability and workers’ comp insurance. Confirm coverage is active and covers all workers, including subcontractors.
Experience: Look for at least 5 years of local experience with projects similar to your flip. Check online reviews, references, and complaint history.
Crew Oversight: Understand if the GC uses in-house crews, subcontractors, or both. Ensure all are insured and that a qualified supervisor is on-site regularly.
Permits & Approvals: The GC should handle all city permits, inspections, and secure the Certificate of Occupancy (CoFO) at completion. Expect regular progress updates.
Payment Schedule: Never pay in full up front. Payments should be milestone-based, with the final payment due only after satisfactory completion. Ensure upfront fees comply with state law.
Detailed Contract: Insist on a clear, itemized contract covering costs, timeline, payment milestones, change orders, insurance, permits, project management, warranty, and a completion guarantee.

content.text: Red Flags to Watch Out For

items: Unexplained negative reviews or unresolved complaints
Lack of experience with similar projects

content.text: Qualifying a GC is one of the most important steps in your fix-and-flip process. If you’re unsure, consider working with experienced investment partners or leveraging professional networks to connect with vetted contractors who can help you achieve a successful, profitable flip.
